instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SO: What is PP3V3_SO? PP3V3_SO is a typo of PP3V3_S0.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Vcore low
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had liquid damage. It was pulling no current and no led on charger, I
cleaned up corrosion <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, removed and cleaned it and replaced. I now have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V5_S0</SIGNAL>
and am pulling 136ma on the power supply. My vcore is only .085v, I can't seem to find
anything pulling vcore down and current draw doesn't seem to indicate a short. <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> has 5v on pin 6 but
I can't find any vcore after that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Vcore low
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> SPI chip.
It could be affected by corrosion too.
Check all SPI termination resistors and traces.

Also check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area; measure pins 7 & 3 voltage.
